title: National Security Decision Making: Theory and Practice
description: This seminar examines national security decision making both from a theoretical perspective and from its execution in practice. The seminar focuses on how decisions are made rather than on national security policy or strategy or theories of international relations. It is divided into three sections. The firstâdrawn, in part, from the instructor's nearly six years on the National Security Council staffâintroduces students to the current structures, processes, institutions, and primary actors involved in national security decision making. The second section delves into analytic and theoretical models of decision making. The seminar concludes with discussions on practical application and execution, has students participate in a crisis simulation, and explores possible reforms. Emphasis throughout is placed on the national security decision-making system of the United States (and particularly the executive branch), but seminar participants are encouraged to examine the systems of other states as well.
